events.text_segment:
A whole hour drifted by, the master sat nodding in his throne, the air was drowsy with the hum of study. By and by, Mr. Dobbins straightened himself up, yawned, then unlocked his desk, and reached for his book, but seemed undecided whether to take it out or leave it. Most of the pupils glanced up languidly, but there were two among them that watched his movements with intent eyes. Mr. Dobbins fingered his book absently for a while, then took it out and settled himself in his chair to read! Tom shot a glance at Becky. He had seen a hunted and helpless rabbit look as she did, with a gun levelled at its head. Instantly he forgot his quarrel with her. Quick—something must be done! done in a flash, too! But the very imminence of the emergency paralyzed his invention. Good!—he had an inspiration! He would run and snatch the book, spring through the door and fly. But his resolution shook for one little instant, and the chance was lost—the master opened the volume. If Tom only had the wasted opportunity back again! Too late. There was no help for Becky now, he said. The next moment the master faced the school. Every eye sank under his gaze. There was that in it which smote even the innocent with fear. There was silence while one might count ten—the master was gathering his wrath. Then he spoke: “Who tore this book?”
There was not a sound. One could have heard a pin drop. The stillness continued; the master searched face after face for signs of guilt.
“Benjamin Rogers, did you tear this book?”
A denial. Another pause.
“Joseph Harper, did you?”
Another denial. Tom’s uneasiness grew more and more intense under the slow torture of these proceedings. The master scanned the ranks of boys—considered a while, then turned to the girls:
“Amy Lawrence?”
A shake of the head.
“Gracie Miller?”
The same sign.
“Susan Harper, did you do this?”
Another negative.

Tom observes Becky, who is pale with terror, trembling as Mr. Dobbins addresses her directly.
Mr. Dobbins insists Becky look him in the face as he asks if she tore the book; her hands rise in a desperate, appealing gesture.
An idea flashes through Tom's mind.

Inspired by the grandeur of his own sacrifice, Tom endures the harshest whipping Mr. Dobbins had ever given without a sound, and also accepts an additional two-hour detention after school with indifference, knowing Becky would wait for him.

events.text_segment:
The next girl was Becky Thatcher. Tom was trembling from head to foot with excitement and a sense of the hopelessness of the situation.
“Rebecca Thatcher” [Tom glanced at her face—it was white with terror]—“did you tear—no, look me in the face” [her hands rose in appeal]—“did you tear this book?”
A thought shot like lightning through Tom’s brain. He sprang to his feet and shouted—“I done it!”
The school stared in perplexity at this incredible folly. Tom stood a moment, to gather his dismembered faculties; and when he stepped forward to go to his punishment the surprise, the gratitude, the adoration that shone upon him out of poor Becky’s eyes seemed pay enough for a hundred floggings. Inspired by the splendor of his own act, he took without an outcry the most merciless flaying that even Mr. Dobbins had ever administered; and also received with indifference the added cruelty of a command to remain two hours after school should be dismissed—for he knew who would wait for him outside till his captivity was done, and not count the tedious time as loss, either.

events.title: The Examination Evening Commences: Setting and Initial Student Recitations
characters: scholars (small boys, big boys, girls, young ladies)
detailed_summary: The anticipated Examination Evening eventually took place.
By eight o'clock that evening, the schoolhouse was aglow with lights and festively decorated with wreaths and garlands of greenery and blossoms.
The schoolmaster, appearing reasonably mellow, occupied his large chair on an elevated platform, with his blackboard positioned behind him.
Rows of benches flanking him on three sides and extending for six rows in front were filled by prominent town members and the students' parents.
To his left, behind the citizens' seating, a large temporary stage held the students scheduled to participate in the evening's program.

This group included rows of young boys, scrubbed clean and dressed in uncomfortably formal attire; rows of awkward older boys; and a large contingent of girls and young women in light-colored dresses, very aware of their exposed arms, heirloom jewelry, ribbons, and hair flowers.

events.text_segment:
In the fulness of time the interesting occasion arrived. At eight in the evening the schoolhouse was brilliantly lighted, and adorned with wreaths and festoons of foliage and flowers. The master sat throned in his great chair upon a raised platform, with his blackboard behind him. He was looking tolerably mellow. Three rows of benches on each side and six rows in front of him were occupied by the dignitaries of the town and by the parents of the pupils. To his left, back of the rows of citizens, was a spacious temporary platform upon which were seated the scholars who were to take part in the exercises of the evening; rows of small boys, washed and dressed to an intolerable state of discomfort; rows of gawky big boys; snowbanks of girls and young ladies clad in lawn and muslin and conspicuously conscious of their bare arms, their grandmothers’ ancient trinkets, their bits of pink and blue ribbon and the flowers in their hair. All the rest of the house was filled with non-participating scholars.
The exercises began. A very little boy stood up and sheepishly recited, “You’d scarce expect one of my age to speak in public on the stage,” etc.—accompanying himself with the painfully exact and spasmodic gestures which a machine might have used—supposing the machine to be a trifle out of order. But he got through safely, though cruelly scared, and got a fine round of applause when he made his manufactured bow and retired.
A little shamefaced girl lisped, “Mary had a little lamb,” etc., performed a compassion-inspiring curtsy, got her meed of applause, and sat down flushed and happy.

The schoolmaster's frown deepened Tom's predicament.
Tom made an effort to continue for a short while but ultimately gave up and left the stage, utterly vanquished.
A faint attempt at applause quickly subsided.

“The Boy Stood on the Burning Deck” followed; also “The Assyrian Came Down,” and other declamatory gems. Then there were reading exercises, and a spelling fight. The meagre Latin class recited with honor. The prime feature of the evening was in order, now—original “compositions” by the young ladies. Each in her turn stepped forward to the edge of the platform, cleared her throat, held up her manuscript (tied with dainty ribbon), and proceeded to read, with labored attention to “expression” and punctuation. The themes were the same that had been illuminated upon similar occasions by their mothers before them, their grandmothers, and doubtless all their ancestors in the female line clear back to the Crusades. “Friendship” was one; “Memories of Other Days”; “Religion in History”; “Dream Land”; “The Advantages of Culture”; “Forms of Political Government Compared and Contrasted”; “Melancholy”; “Filial Love”; “Heart Longings,” etc., etc.
A prevalent feature in these compositions was a nursed and petted melancholy; another was a wasteful and opulent gush of “fine language”; another was a tendency to lug in by the ears particularly prized words and phrases until they were worn entirely out; and a peculiarity that conspicuously marked and marred them was the inveterate and intolerable sermon that wagged its crippled tail at the end of each and every one of them. No matter what the subject might be, a brainracking effort was made to squirm it into some aspect or other that the moral and religious mind could contemplate with edification. The glaring insincerity of these sermons was not sufficient to compass the banishment of the fashion from the schools, and it is not sufficient today; it never will be sufficient while the world stands, perhaps. There is no school in all our land where the young ladies do not feel obliged to close their compositions with a sermon; and you will find that the sermon of the most frivolous and the least religious girl in the school is always the longest and the most relentlessly pious. But enough of this. Homely truth is unpalatable.

events.text_segment:
Let us return to the “Examination.” The first composition that was read was one entitled “Is this, then, Life?” Perhaps the reader can endure an extract from it:
“In the common walks of life, with what delightful emotions does the youthful mind look forward to some anticipated scene of festivity! Imagination is busy sketching rose-tinted pictures of joy. In fancy, the voluptuous votary of fashion sees herself amid the festive throng, ‘the observed of all observers.’ Her graceful form, arrayed in snowy robes, is whirling through the mazes of the joyous dance; her eye is brightest, her step is lightest in the gay assembly.
“In such delicious fancies time quickly glides by, and the welcome hour arrives for her entrance into the Elysian world, of which she has had such bright dreams. How fairy-like does everything appear to her enchanted vision! Each new scene is more charming than the last. But after a while she finds that beneath this goodly exterior, all is vanity, the flattery which once charmed her soul, now grates harshly upon her ear; the ballroom has lost its charms; and with wasted health and imbittered heart, she turns away with the conviction that earthly pleasures cannot satisfy the longings of the soul!”
And so forth and so on. There was a buzz of gratification from time to time during the reading, accompanied by whispered ejaculations of “How sweet!” “How eloquent!” “So true!” etc., and after the thing had closed with a peculiarly afflicting sermon the applause was enthusiastic.
Then arose a slim, melancholy girl, whose face had the “interesting” paleness that comes of pills and indigestion, and read a “poem.” Two stanzas of it will do:
“A MISSOURI MAIDEN’S FAREWELL TO ALABAMA
“Alabama, goodbye! I love thee well!
    But yet for a while do I leave thee now!
Sad, yes, sad thoughts of thee my heart doth swell,
    And burning recollections throng my brow!
For I have wandered through thy flowery woods;
    Have roamed and read near Tallapoosa’s stream;
Have listened to Tallassee’s warring floods,
    And wooed on Coosa’s side Aurora’s beam.

“Yet shame I not to bear an o’erfull heart,
    Nor blush to turn behind my tearful eyes;
’Tis from no stranger land I now must part,
    ’Tis to no strangers left I yield these sighs.
Welcome and home were mine within this State,
    Whose vales I leave—whose spires fade fast from me
And cold must be mine eyes, and heart, and tête,
    When, dear Alabama! they turn cold on thee!”
There were very few there who knew what “tête” meant, but the poem was very satisfactory, nevertheless.
Next appeared a dark-complexioned, black-eyed, black-haired young lady, who paused an impressive moment, assumed a tragic expression, and began to read in a measured, solemn tone:
Dark and tempestuous was night. Around the throne on high not a single star quivered; but the deep intonations of the heavy thunder constantly vibrated upon the ear; whilst the terrific lightning revelled in angry mood through the cloudy chambers of heaven, seeming to scorn the power exerted over its terror by the illustrious Franklin! Even the boisterous winds unanimously came forth from their mystic homes, and blustered about as if to enhance by their aid the wildness of the scene.
At such a time, so dark, so dreary, for human sympathy my very spirit sighed; but instead thereof,
 ‘My dearest friend, my counsellor, my comforter and guide—
        My joy in grief, my second bliss in joy,’ came to my side.
She moved like one of those bright beings pictured in the sunny walks of fancy’s Eden by the romantic and young, a queen of beauty unadorned save by her own transcendent loveliness. So soft was her step, it failed to make even a sound, and but for the magical thrill imparted by her genial touch, as other unobtrusive beauties, she would have glided away unperceived—unsought. A strange sadness rested upon her features, like icy tears upon the robe of December, as she pointed to the contending elements without, and bade me contemplate the two beings presented.
This nightmare occupied some ten pages of manuscript and wound up with a sermon so destructive of all hope to non-Presbyterians that it took the first prize. This composition was considered to be the very finest effort of the evening. The mayor of the village, in delivering the prize to the author of it, made a warm speech in which he said that it was by far the most “eloquent” thing he had ever listened to, and that Daniel Webster himself might well be proud of it.
It may be remarked, in passing, that the number of compositions in which the word “beauteous” was over-fondled, and human experience referred to as “life’s page,” was up to the usual average.

events.title: The Cat, the Wig, and the Gilded Pate: The Boys' Revenge Fulfilled
detailed_summary: The schoolmaster, now very relaxed and almost friendly, moved his chair, turned away from the audience, and started to draw a map of America on the blackboard for a geography class exercise.
However, his unsteady hand resulted in a poorly executed drawing, prompting quiet laughter to spread through the audience.
He recognized the problem and attempted to correct it by erasing and redrawing lines, but this only made the distortions worse, and the laughter grew more noticeable.
He then concentrated entirely on his work, seemingly resolved not to be deterred by the amusement.
He sensed all eyes on him and believed he was improving, yet the tittering persisted and even intensified.
The reason for the increasing amusement was a cat being lowered through a hatch in the ceiling directly above him, suspended by a string around its hindquarters.
The cat had a cloth tied around its head and jaw to prevent it from meowing.
As it slowly descended, it arched its body upwards, clawing at the string, then swung downwards, clawing at the empty air.
The laughter grew louder as the cat came within inches of the engrossed teacher's head.
Suddenly, the cat descended further, grabbed the master's wig with its claws, held onto it, and was swiftly pulled back up into the attic, still holding its trophy.
The light then brightly illuminated the master's bald scalp, which, it was revealed, the signpainter's son had gilded.
This event brought the meeting to an immediate and chaotic end.
The boys had successfully exacted their revenge.
Vacation had arrived.

events.text_segment:
Now the master, mellow almost to the verge of geniality, put his chair aside, turned his back to the audience, and began to draw a map of America on the blackboard, to exercise the geography class upon. But he made a sad business of it with his unsteady hand, and a smothered titter rippled over the house. He knew what the matter was, and set himself to right it. He sponged out lines and remade them; but he only distorted them more than ever, and the tittering was more pronounced. He threw his entire attention upon his work, now, as if determined not to be put down by the mirth. He felt that all eyes were fastened upon him; he imagined he was succeeding, and yet the tittering continued; it even manifestly increased. And well it might. There was a garret above, pierced with a scuttle over his head; and down through this scuttle came a cat, suspended around the haunches by a string; she had a rag tied about her head and jaws to keep her from mewing; as she slowly descended she curved upward and clawed at the string, she swung downward and clawed at the intangible air. The tittering rose higher and higher—the cat was within six inches of the absorbed teacher’s head—down, down, a little lower, and she grabbed his wig with her desperate claws, clung to it, and was snatched up into the garret in an instant with her trophy still in her possession! And how the light did blaze abroad from the master’s bald pate—for the signpainter’s boy had gilded it!
That broke up the meeting. The boys were avenged. Vacation had come.

The master saw the mishap, and straightened the rule; but crookedness is catching, and the mischief of it was done. He tried to wipe it out and draw it again, but the flat of the rule plowed such an indifferent line that it was worse than the first. "Mr. Dobbins's curve," was the name the boys gave it in private. Many a laugh it cost them, and it was repeated every day thereafter for seventy years. Every attempt to mend it did but damage it further. The boys tittered and whispered, they were at work lavishing a generous handful of paper wads on the innocent blackboard. But the master paid no heed. Thinks he, "This is a class in geography; an examination, and it would be irregular to notice this misconduct. I will wait till after school." He wiped out with his hand, and drew again. The new line was as wavy as the other, and the titter rose higher. He wiped again, with his sleeve—still worse; he wiped with the flat of his hand—the board became more and more clouded with chalk dust, and the lines clearer and clearer in the midst of it. By this time the audience were laughing openly; it was getting to be a joke, past a joke, a regular comedy. The master, however, was not conscious of any defect in his performance; he was absorbed in his work, and believed he was getting along splendidly. He felt a sense of triumph, and was about to turn and face the audience, when he heard a slight noise above his head, and a moment later a cat was seen descending from the ceiling, suspended by a string around its hindquarters. The cat was in a state of great excitement, and was clawing and struggling with all its might. It was evident that it was not used to being suspended in this way. The audience were in a roar of laughter, and the master, turning to see what was the matter, saw the cat, and the string, and the audience, and the whole thing flashed upon him. He made a grab for the cat, but it was too late. The cat, with a desperate effort, reached the master's head, and with a wild shriek of triumph, seized the master's wig with its claws, and was instantly whisked up into the attic, carrying the wig with it. The master stood for a moment, a picture of astonishment and rage, and then, with a yell of fury, he sprang at the boys, who were by this time in a state of frantic excitement. The meeting broke up in a riot, and the boys, with a shout of triumph, rushed out of the schoolhouse, and scattered in all directions. The master, left alone in the schoolhouse, stood for a moment, a picture of despair, and then, with a groan, he sank into his chair, and buried his face in his hands. The signpainter's boy, who had gilded the master's bald head, was the hero of the hour, and was carried in triumph through the village. The boys had had their revenge, and the school was broken up for the season.

events.title: Tom's Short-Lived Temperance and the Judge's Demise
detailed_summary: Tom Sawyer enrolled in the Cadets of Temperance, drawn by the attractiveness of their official attire.
He committed to refraining from smoking, chewing tobacco, and using swear words for the duration of his membership.
He soon realized that making a promise not to do something was the most effective way to create an urge to do that specific thing.
Tom found himself increasingly plagued by a powerful desire to drink and use profanity.
The only thing preventing him from leaving the order was the hope of an opportunity to show off his red sash.
The Fourth of July was approaching, but he quickly abandoned that hope, within forty-eight hours of joining, and instead focused on Judge Frazer, a justice of the peace.
Judge Frazer appeared to be near death, and Tom anticipated a large public funeral due to the Judge's high official status, which would be an occasion to wear his regalia.
Over three days, Tom was intensely preoccupied with the Judge's health and eager for updates.
Sometimes his optimism soared, prompting him to take out his uniform and practice poses in the mirror.
However, the Judge's condition had a very frustrating pattern of improvement and decline.
Eventually, the Judge was reported to be improving and then recovering.
Tom was thoroughly annoyed and felt personally aggrieved by this development.
He immediately tendered his resignation from the Cadets.
On that very same night, the Judge experienced a sudden worsening of his condition and died.
Tom made a firm decision never to place his trust in such an unpredictable individual again.
The funeral was a grand affair.
The Cadets marched in a manner seemingly intended to make the late Judge Frazer envious.
Tom, however, was once again free from his temperance commitments, which brought him a sense of relief.
He discovered, to his own astonishment, that he no longer had the inclination to drink or swear.
The mere fact that he was permitted to do so had eliminated the desire and the appeal of these activities.

events.text_segment:
Tom joined the new order of Cadets of Temperance, being attracted by the showy character of their “regalia.” He promised to abstain from smoking, chewing, and profanity as long as he remained a member. Now he found out a new thing—namely, that to promise not to do a thing is the surest way in the world to make a body want to go and do that very thing. Tom soon found himself tormented with a desire to drink and swear; the desire grew to be so intense that nothing but the hope of a chance to display himself in his red sash kept him from withdrawing from the order. Fourth of July was coming; but he soon gave that up—gave it up before he had worn his shackles over forty-eight hours—and fixed his hopes upon old Judge Frazer, justice of the peace, who was apparently on his deathbed and would have a big public funeral, since he was so high an official. During three days Tom was deeply concerned about the Judge’s condition and hungry for news of it. Sometimes his hopes ran high—so high that he would venture to get out his regalia and practise before the looking-glass. But the Judge had a most discouraging way of fluctuating. At last he was pronounced upon the mend—and then convalescent. Tom was disgusted; and felt a sense of injury, too. He handed in his resignation at once—and that night the Judge suffered a relapse and died. Tom resolved that he would never trust a man like that again.
The funeral was a fine thing. The Cadets paraded in a style calculated to kill the late member with envy. Tom was a free boy again, however—there was something in that. He could drink and swear, now—but found to his surprise that he did not want to. The simple fact that he could, took the desire away, and the charm of it.

events.title: Vacation Disappointments and Failed Distractions
detailed_summary: Tom soon found that his eagerly awaited vacation was becoming somewhat boring and uneventful.
He made an attempt to keep a diary, but nothing of interest occurred for three days, leading him to abandon the effort.
The town's very first negro minstrel show arrived, creating a significant stir and excitement.
In response, Tom and Joe Harper organized their own group of performers, enjoying this activity for two days.
Even the anticipated Glorious Fourth of July turned out to be somewhat of a letdown due to heavy rainfall, which led to the cancellation of the procession.
Furthermore, Mr. Benton, a genuine United States Senator whom Tom had imagined to be an immense figure, was a major disappointment as he was not nearly twenty-five feet tall, nor even close to it.

A circus came to town, inspiring the boys to play circus for the following three days in makeshift tents constructed from rag carpeting; admission was set at three pins for boys and two for girls, after which this activity was also discontinued.
A phrenologist and a mesmerizer visited the town but soon departed, leaving the village feeling even more lackluster and depressing than before.
There were a few parties attended by both boys and girls, but these events were so infrequent and enjoyable that they only served to make the periods of emptiness between them feel more acute.
Becky Thatcher had traveled to her family's home in Constantinople for the vacation, meaning there was no source of happiness or brightness in Tom's life.
The terrible secret concerning the murder was a persistent source of distress for Tom, like a chronic and painful disease.

Tom presently wondered to find that his coveted vacation was beginning to hang a little heavily on his hands.
He attempted a diary—but nothing happened during three days, and so he abandoned it.
The first of all the negro minstrel shows came to town, and made a sensation. Tom and Joe Harper got up a band of performers and were happy for two days.
Even the Glorious Fourth was in some sense a failure, for it rained hard, there was no procession in consequence, and the greatest man in the world (as Tom supposed), Mr. Benton, an actual United States Senator, proved an overwhelming disappointment—for he was not twenty-five feet high, nor even anywhere in the neighborhood of it.
A circus came. The boys played circus for three days afterward in tents made of rag carpeting—admission, three pins for boys, two for girls—and then circusing was abandoned.
A phrenologist and a mesmerizer came—and went again and left the village duller and drearier than ever.
There were some boys-and-girls’ parties, but they were so few and so delightful that they only made the aching voids between ache the harder.
Becky Thatcher was gone to her Constantinople home to stay with her parents during vacation—so there was no bright side to life anywhere.
The dreadful secret of the murder was a chronic misery. It was a very cancer for permanency and pain.

Agent_Extraction.simple_agent_extraction: Tom presently wondered to find that his coveted vacation was beginning to hang a little heavily on his hands. He had imagined a thousand delightful ways of spending each hour, but he had not counted on the dreary sameness of every day. He was restless, he was discontented. The novelty of "going barefoot" had lost its charm; the novelty of "going fishing" was stale; the novelty of "going swimming" was gone. Tobacco-chewing began to lose its sweetness, and so did licorice. Stabbing "Injun Joe" with his pocket-knife was becoming a blunted pleasure. He tried to keep a diary, but the entries were not stimulating: "Monday, nothing happened. Tuesday, nothing happened. Wednesday, nothing happened." He gave it up. The Fourth of July came, but gloom brooded over it. There was a grand procession to the church, and a long prayer, and an oration, and then a picnic, and a great deal of noise and hilarity and patriotism. But the rain came down in torrents, and the procession was a sorry sight, and the picnic was a miserable failure. The Senator, Mr. Benton, was there, and Tom had imagined him a vast and awful figure, twenty-five feet high, and he was a little disappointed to see him a mere man. A negro minstrel show came to town, and created a stir. Tom and Joe Harper got up a company of their own, and gave two performances in a barn, with a "burnt-cork" face and a "banjo" made of a sieve and a broomstick. They had a good time, but it didn't last. A circus came, and Tom and Joe and Huck and the rest played circus for three days in a rag-carpet tent, with admission three pins for boys and two for girls. Then that palled. A phrenologist and a mesmerizer came, and went again and left the village duller than it was before. There were some parties, and they were pleasant, but they were so few and far between that they only made the periods of emptiness between them the more dreary. Becky Thatcher was gone to her father's and mother's at Constantinople, and Tom's heart ached for her. No light, no hope, in his life. The terrible secret of the murder was upon him, a chronic, remorseless disease.

Then came the measles.
During two long weeks Tom lay a prisoner, dead to the world and its happenings. He was very ill, he was interested in nothing. When he got upon his feet at last and moved feebly downtown, a melancholy change had come over everything and every creature. There had been a “revival,” and everybody had “got religion,” not only the adults, but even the boys and girls. Tom went about, hoping against hope for the sight of one blessed sinful face, but disappointment crossed him everywhere. He found Joe Harper studying a Testament, and turned sadly away from the depressing spectacle. He sought Ben Rogers, and found him visiting the poor with a basket of tracts. He hunted up Jim Hollis, who called his attention to the precious blessing of his late measles as a warning. Every boy he encountered added another ton to his depression; and when, in desperation, he flew for refuge at last to the bosom of Huckleberry Finn and was received with a Scriptural quotation, his heart broke and he crept home and to bed realizing that he alone of all the town was lost, forever and forever.

Tom concealed himself under his bedclothes, waiting in a state of horrified anticipation for what he believed was his certain doom.

He believed he had strained the patience of the divine powers to the breaking point and that this storm was the direct consequence.

detailed_summary: After some time, the storm exhausted its energy and ended without achieving what Tom perceived as its goal.
Tom's first instinct was to feel thankful and to decide to change his ways for the better.
His second thought, however, was to pause and reconsider, as there might not be any more such storms.
The next day, the doctors were called back; Tom had experienced a relapse of his illness.
The three weeks he spent confined to his bed this time felt like an entire lifetime.
When he was finally able to go out again, he felt hardly any gratitude for having been spared, recalling how isolated his situation was and how utterly alone and dejected he felt.

He wandered dejectedly down the street and came across Jim Hollis acting as a judge in a children's make-believe court that was trying a cat for the murder of a bird, with the bird's body present as evidence.
He then found Joe Harper and Huckleberry Finn in an alley, engaged in eating a stolen melon.
Tom realized that these unfortunate boys, much like himself, had also experienced a 'relapse' from their recent religious piety.

events.title: Tom and Huck Reaffirm Their Secret Oath Amidst Trial Anxiety
detailed_summary: The commencement of the murder trial stirs the village, making it the dominant topic of conversation.
Tom is deeply unsettled by any mention of the murder, fearing that references to it are subtle attempts to gauge his knowledge.
Despite not understanding how he could be suspected, Tom lives in a constant state of anxiety.
He seeks out Huck in a private location to discuss their shared secret and alleviate some of his distress.
Tom's primary concern is to confirm that Huck has not revealed anything about what they witnessed.
Huck firmly reassures Tom that he has never spoken a word about the incident.
Huck underscores the grave danger they would face if their knowledge became public, stating they wouldn't survive long.
Feeling somewhat more at ease, Tom presses further, asking Huck if anyone could coerce him into confessing.
Huck emphatically states that only a desire for Injun Joe to kill him would make him tell, asserting there's no other way he'd reveal the truth.
Tom agrees that their safety lies in silence, and they decide to renew their vow of secrecy with solemn oaths for extra assurance.

events.text_segment:
At last the sleepy atmosphere was stirred—and vigorously: the murder trial came on in the court. It became the absorbing topic of village talk immediately. Tom could not get away from it. Every reference to the murder sent a shudder to his heart, for his troubled conscience and fears almost persuaded him that these remarks were put forth in his hearing as “feelers”; he did not see how he could be suspected of knowing anything about the murder, but still he could not be comfortable in the midst of this gossip. It kept him in a cold shiver all the time. He took Huck to a lonely place to have a talk with him. It would be some relief to unseal his tongue for a little while; to divide his burden of distress with another sufferer. Moreover, he wanted to assure himself that Huck had remained discreet.
“Huck, have you ever told anybody about—that?”
“’Bout what?”
“You know what.”
“Oh—’course I haven’t.”
“Never a word?”
“Never a solitary word, so help me. What makes you ask?”
“Well, I was afeard.”
“Why, Tom Sawyer, we wouldn’t be alive two days if that got found out. You know that.”
Tom felt more comfortable. After a pause:
“Huck, they couldn’t anybody get you to tell, could they?”
“Get me to tell? Why, if I wanted that halfbreed devil to drownd me they could get me to tell. They ain’t no different way.”
“Well, that’s all right, then. I reckon we’re safe as long as we keep mum. But let’s swear again, anyway. It’s more surer.”
“I’m agreed.”
So they swore again with dread solemnities.

events.title: Boys' Guilt, Potter's Gratitude, and a Jailhouse Visit
detailed_summary: Tom inquires about the prevalent village talk, which Huck confirms is entirely focused on Muff Potter, causing Huck continuous anxiety.
Tom shares that he experiences similar discomfort and expresses his belief that Potter is doomed, questioning Huck if he ever feels sympathy for him.
Huck admits to frequently feeling sorry for Potter, acknowledging Potter's lack of social standing but also his harmless nature and past acts of kindness, such as sharing food and offering support.
Tom reciprocates, recalling how Potter mended his kites and helped with his fishing line, and expresses a wish to free Potter from jail.
Huck dismisses the idea of freeing Potter as futile, believing he would inevitably be recaptured.
Both boys express their dismay at hearing Potter so harshly condemned for a crime they know he didn't commit.
They discuss the villagers' harsh judgment, including remarks about Potter's villainous appearance and threats of lynching if he were freed.
Their long conversation provides little comfort, and as twilight descends, they find themselves lingering near the isolated jail, perhaps with a vague hope for a miraculous resolution.
Following a familiar routine, the boys approach Potter's cell grating to give him tobacco and matches, as he is on the ground floor without guards.
Potter's gratitude for their offerings has always troubled their consciences, but this time it affects them more profoundly.
They feel intensely cowardly and treacherous when Potter thanks them, calling them his only true friends in town and promising not to forget their loyalty.
Potter acknowledges his wrongdoing, attributing it to being drunk and crazed, and accepts that he must face the consequences, hoping it is for the best.
He implores the boys never to get drunk, so they avoid his fate, and expresses how much comfort their friendly faces bring him in his isolation.
Potter asks to touch their hands through the bars, remarking on their smallness but acknowledging the significant help they've provided and would provide if they could.

events.text_segment:
“What is the talk around, Huck? I’ve heard a power of it.”
“Talk? Well, it’s just Muff Potter, Muff Potter, Muff Potter all the time. It keeps me in a sweat, constant, so’s I want to hide som’ers.”
“That’s just the same way they go on round me. I reckon he’s a goner. Don’t you feel sorry for him, sometimes?”
“Most always—most always. He ain’t no account; but then he hain’t ever done anything to hurt anybody. Just fishes a little, to get money to get drunk on—and loafs around considerable; but lord, we all do that—leastways most of us—preachers and such like. But he’s kind of good—he give me half a fish, once, when there warn’t enough for two; and lots of times he’s kind of stood by me when I was out of luck.”
“Well, he’s mended kites for me, Huck, and knitted hooks on to my line. I wish we could get him out of there.”
“My! we couldn’t get him out, Tom. And besides, ’twouldn’t do any good; they’d ketch him again.”
“Yes—so they would. But I hate to hear ’em abuse him so like the dickens when he never done—that.”
“I do too, Tom. Lord, I hear ’em say he’s the bloodiest looking villain in this country, and they wonder he wasn’t ever hung before.”
“Yes, they talk like that, all the time. I’ve heard ’em say that if he was to get free they’d lynch him.”
“And they’d do it, too.”
The boys had a long talk, but it brought them little comfort. As the twilight drew on, they found themselves hanging about the neighborhood of the little isolated jail, perhaps with an undefined hope that something would happen that might clear away their difficulties. But nothing happened; there seemed to be no angels or fairies interested in this luckless captive.
The boys did as they had often done before—went to the cell grating and gave Potter some tobacco and matches. He was on the ground floor and there were no guards.
His gratitude for their gifts had always smote their consciences before—it cut deeper than ever, this time. They felt cowardly and treacherous to the last degree when Potter said:
“You’ve been mighty good to me, boys—better’n anybody else in this town. And I don’t forget it, I don’t. Often I says to myself, says I, ‘I used to mend all the boys’ kites and things, and show ’em where the good fishin’ places was, and befriend ’em what I could, and now they’ve all forgot old Muff when he’s in trouble; but Tom don’t, and Huck don’t—they don’t forget him,’ says I, ‘and I don’t forget them.’ Well, boys, I done an awful thing—drunk and crazy at the time—that’s the only way I account for it—and now I got to swing for it, and it’s right. events.text_segment:
Tom went home miserable, and his dreams that night were full of horrors. The next day and the day after, he hung about the courtroom, drawn by an almost irresistible impulse to go in, but forcing himself to stay out. Huck was having the same experience. They studiously avoided each other. Each wandered away, from time to time, but the same dismal fascination always brought them back presently. Tom kept his ears open when idlers sauntered out of the courtroom, but invariably heard distressing news—the toils were closing more and more relentlessly around poor Potter. At the end of the second day the village talk was to the effect that Injun Joe’s evidence stood firm and unshaken, and that there was not the slightest question as to what the jury’s verdict would be.
Tom was out late, that night, and came to bed through the window. He was in a tremendous state of excitement. It was hours before he got to sleep. All the village flocked to the courthouse the next morning, for this was to be the great day. Both sexes were about equally represented in the packed audience. After a long wait the jury filed in and took their places; shortly afterward, Potter, pale and haggard, timid and hopeless, was brought in, with chains upon him, and seated where all the curious eyes could stare at him; no less conspicuous was Injun Joe, stolid as ever. There was another pause, and then the judge arrived and the sheriff proclaimed the opening of the court. The usual whisperings among the lawyers and gathering together of papers followed. These details and accompanying delays worked up an atmosphere of preparation that was as impressive as it was fascinating.

It was said that when some sympathizing souls tried to raise a doubt about it in a dispute with the prosecutor, they were put down magnificently with arguments which showed that the mere fact that he stood mute, and was not trying to escape, was simply additional proof of guilt, for why shouldn't he proclaim his innocence if he were innocent?—and why shouldn't he fly if he were guilty? This was unanswerable. At last that trying week was gone, and Monday came, big with fate. An awful tide of people poured into the village all the morning. The jury was impaneled, and the trial began. The lawyers made their opening statements. The witnesses were called. One after another they testified—old Mr. Jones, the doctor, the sheriff—all giving their evidence against Muff Potter. It was a long and tedious process, and the suspense was terrible. Tom and Huck were there, of course, hidden away in a corner where they could see and hear without being seen. They were pale and trembling, and their hearts were heavy with guilt and fear. The prosecution's case was strong, and it seemed that nothing could save Muff Potter. The villagers looked on with grim satisfaction, convinced of his guilt. The judge sat on the bench, grave and impassive. The lawyers bustled about, rustling papers and whispering to each other. The air was thick with tension and anticipation. Finally, the prosecution rested its case. It was the defense's turn. Muff Potter's lawyer rose, a young man who seemed nervous and unsure of himself. He called his first witness. It was Tom Sawyer.

events.text_segment:
“Thomas Sawyer, where were you on the seventeenth of June, about the hour of midnight?”
Tom glanced at Injun Joe’s iron face and his tongue failed him. The audience listened breathless, but the words refused to come. After a few moments, however, the boy got a little of his strength back, and managed to put enough of it into his voice to make part of the house hear:
“In the graveyard!”
“A little bit louder, please. Don’t be afraid. You were—”
“In the graveyard.”
A contemptuous smile flitted across Injun Joe’s face.
“Were you anywhere near Horse Williams’ grave?”
“Yes, sir.”
“Speak up—just a trifle louder. How near were you?”
“Near as I am to you.”
“Were you hidden, or not?”
“I was hid.”
“Where?”
“Behind the elms that’s on the edge of the grave.”
Injun Joe gave a barely perceptible start.
“Any one with you?”
“Yes, sir. I went there with—”
“Wait—wait a moment. Never mind mentioning your companion’s name. We will produce him at the proper time. Did you carry anything there with you.”
Tom hesitated and looked confused.
“Speak out, my boy—don’t be diffident. The truth is always respectable. What did you take there?”
“Only a—a—dead cat.”
There was a ripple of mirth, which the court checked.
“We will produce the skeleton of that cat. Now, my boy, tell us everything that occurred—tell it in your own way—don’t skip anything, and don’t be afraid.”
Tom began—hesitatingly at first, but as he warmed to his subject his words flowed more and more easily; in a little while every sound ceased but his own voice; every eye fixed itself upon him; with parted lips and bated breath the audience hung upon his words, taking no note of time, rapt in the ghastly fascinations of the tale. The strain upon pent emotion reached its climax when the boy said:
“—and as the doctor fetched the board around and Muff Potter fell, Injun Joe jumped with the knife and—”
Crash! Quick as lightning the halfbreed sprang for a window, tore his way through all opposers, and was gone!

events.title: Tom's Treasure Hunting Inspiration and Huck's Recruitment
detailed_summary: A strong desire to search for hidden treasure suddenly overtakes Tom.
He unsuccessfully tries to find Joe Harper and then Ben Rogers to join him.
Tom eventually encounters Huck Finn, who is known as 'the Red-Handed'.
Tom takes Huck to a secluded spot and privately shares his treasure-hunting idea.
Huck readily agrees, being always open to entertaining activities that don't require money, as he possesses an abundance of free time.
Huck inquires about their intended digging location.

Tom took him to a private place and opened the matter to him confidentially. Huck was willing. events.title: The Lore of Hidden Treasures and Robbers' Habits
detailed_summary: Tom explains that treasure isn't found just anywhere.

He elaborates that it's hidden in very specific places, such as islands, in rotten chests under the branches of old dead trees where the shadow falls at midnight, but most commonly under the floors of haunted houses.
Huck asks who is responsible for hiding the treasure.
Tom replies, with some disdain, that robbers are the ones who hide treasure, not figures like Sunday-school superintendents.
Huck comments that if he had treasure, he'd spend it and enjoy himself rather than hide it.
Tom concurs but states that robbers operate differently, always choosing to hide their loot and leave it.
Huck questions if robbers don't return for their treasure.
Tom explains that robbers intend to return but often forget the hiding spots or die, leaving the treasure to become rusty over time.
He adds that eventually, someone discovers an old, yellowed paper with coded instructions, usually signs and hieroglyphics, that takes about a week to decipher.
Huck expresses confusion over the word 'hy’roglyphics'.

segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: “Hyro—which?”

events.text_segment:
“Oh, most anywhere.”
“Why, is it hid all around?”
“No, indeed it ain’t. It’s hid in mighty particular places, Huck—sometimes on islands, sometimes in rotten chests under the end of a limb of an old dead tree, just where the shadow falls at midnight; but mostly under the floor in ha’nted houses.”
“Who hides it?”
“Why, robbers, of course—who’d you reckon? Sunday-school sup’rintendents?”
“I don’t know. If ’twas mine I wouldn’t hide it; I’d spend it and have a good time.”
“So would I. But robbers don’t do that way. They always hide it and leave it there.”
“Don’t they come after it any more?”
“No, they think they will, but they generally forget the marks, or else they die. Anyway, it lays there a long time and gets rusty; and by and by somebody finds an old yellow paper that tells how to find the marks—a paper that’s got to be ciphered over about a week because it’s mostly signs and hy’roglyphics.”
“Hyro—which?”

events.title: Planning the Dig and Discussing Potential Riches
detailed_summary: Tom clarifies that hieroglyphics are pictures and symbols that appear to lack meaning.
Huck asks if Tom possesses one of these coded papers, to which Tom answers no.
Huck then questions how they will locate the treasure's marks without such a paper.
Tom dismisses the need for specific marks, reiterating that treasures are typically buried under haunted houses, on islands, or beneath dead trees with a prominent limb.
He mentions they have previously explored Jackson's Island and could do so again, and also notes the existence of an old haunted house and numerous dead-limbed trees.
Huck asks if treasure is located under all such trees, which Tom denies.

events.title: Daytime Dig Preparations, Dreams of Treasure, and Tom's Marriage Plans
detailed_summary: Huck expresses his contentment with the idea of finding a hundred dollars, stating he has no need for diamonds.
Tom, however, insists he wouldn't pass up diamonds, highlighting their significant value.
They discuss the rarity and worth of diamonds, with Tom remarking that kings possess them in abundance.
A humorous misunderstanding arises about kings 'hopping around,' which Tom quickly clarifies.
Tom explains that kings typically have only a single given name.
Huck finds this peculiar and undesirable, comparing it to the naming conventions for Black individuals at the time.
Huck redirects the conversation, asking Tom where they will begin their digging.
Tom suggests they start with an old dead-limb tree located on the hill on the other side of Still-House branch, to which Huck agrees.
They procure a damaged pickaxe and a shovel and embark on a three-mile walk to the chosen spot.
Arriving hot and out of breath, they rest in the shade of a nearby elm tree and have a smoke.
Tom expresses his enjoyment of the adventure, and Huck concurs.
Tom then asks Huck how he plans to use his share of any treasure they might find.
Huck outlines his desires: daily pie and soda, and attending every circus that comes to town, envisioning a very merry time.
Tom questions whether Huck intends to save any of his potential fortune.
Huck dismisses the idea of saving, fearing his absent father would return and confiscate any accumulated money.
Huck then asks Tom about his own plans for the treasure.
Tom reveals his intentions: to buy a new drum, a genuine sword, a red necktie, a bull pup, and to get married.
Huck is visibly shocked by Tom's plan to marry.
Tom confirms his intention.
Huck exclaims that Tom must not be in his right mind, calling marriage the most foolish thing he could do and citing his own parents' constant fighting as an example.
Tom confidently states that the girl he plans to marry will not be prone to fighting.
Huck expresses skepticism, opining that all girls are essentially the same and will 'comb a body' (nag or scold), advising Tom to reconsider.
Huck asks for the girl's name.
Tom defers answering, promising to tell him at a later time.
Huck resigns himself to this, but expresses concern that Tom's marriage will leave him feeling more alone than ever.
Tom reassures Huck that he won't be alone and can come live with him and his future wife, then urges him to get up so they can begin digging.

events.text_segment:
“That’s bully. Plenty bully enough for me. Just you gimme the hundred dollars and I don’t want no di’monds.”
“All right. But I bet you I ain’t going to throw off on di’monds. Some of ’em’s worth twenty dollars apiece—there ain’t any, hardly, but’s worth six bits or a dollar.”
“No! Is that so?”
“Cert’nly—anybody’ll tell you so. Hain’t you ever seen one, Huck?”
“Not as I remember.”
“Oh, kings have slathers of them.”
“Well, I don’ know no kings, Tom.”
“I reckon you don’t. But if you was to go to Europe you’d see a raft of ’em hopping around.”
“Do they hop?”
“Hop?—your granny! No!”
“Well, what did you say they did, for?”
“Shucks, I only meant you’d see ’em—not hopping, of course—what do they want to hop for?—but I mean you’d just see ’em—scattered around, you know, in a kind of a general way. Like that old humpbacked Richard.”
“Richard? What’s his other name?”
“He didn’t have any other name. Kings don’t have any but a given name.”
“No?”
“But they don’t.”
“Well, if they like it, Tom, all right; but I don’t want to be a king and have only just a given name, like a nigger. But say—where you going to dig first?”
“Well, I don’t know. S’pose we tackle that old dead-limb tree on the hill t’other side of Still-House branch?”
“I’m agreed.”
So they got a crippled pick and a shovel, and set out on their three-mile tramp. They arrived hot and panting, and threw themselves down in the shade of a neighboring elm to rest and have a smoke.
“I like this,” said Tom.
“So do I.”
“Say, Huck, if we find a treasure here, what you going to do with your share?”
“Well, I’ll have pie and a glass of soda every day, and I’ll go to every circus that comes along. I bet I’ll have a gay time.”
“Well, ain’t you going to save any of it?”
“Save it? What for?”
“Why, so as to have something to live on, by and by.”
“Oh, that ain’t any use. Pap would come back to thish-yer town some day and get his claws on it if I didn’t hurry up, and I tell you he’d clean it out pretty quick. What you going to do with yourn, Tom?”
“I’m going to buy a new drum, and a sure’nough sword, and a red necktie and a bull pup, and get married.”
“Married!”
“That’s it.”
“Tom, you—why, you ain’t in your right mind.”
“Wait—you’ll see.”
“Well, that’s the foolishest thing you could do. Look at pap and my mother. Fight! Why, they used to fight all the time. I remember, mighty well.”
“That ain’t anything. The girl I’m going to marry won’t fight.”
“Tom, I reckon they’re all alike. They’ll all comb a body. Now you better think ’bout this awhile. I tell you you better. What’s the name of the gal?”
“It ain’t a gal at all—it’s a girl.”
“It’s all the same, I reckon; some says gal, some says girl—both’s right, like enough. Anyway, what’s her name, Tom?”
“I’ll tell you some time—not now.”
“All right—that’ll do. Only if you get married I’ll be more lonesomer than ever.”
“No you won’t. You’ll come and live with me. Now stir out of this and we’ll go to digging.”

events.title: Fruitless Daytime Digging and a Crucial Realization
detailed_summary: The boys dig energetically for half an hour but find nothing.
They toil for another half hour with the same lack of results.
Huck asks if treasure is always buried so deeply.
Tom replies that it's not always, or even generally, buried deep, and suggests they might be in the wrong location.
They choose a new spot and start digging again.
The work feels somewhat tedious, but they continue to make progress, digging in silence for a while.
Eventually, Huck leans on his shovel, wipes sweat from his brow, and asks where Tom plans to dig next.
Tom suggests they might try the old tree on Cardiff Hill, behind the widow's house.
Huck agrees it sounds like a good spot but voices concern that the widow might claim any treasure found, as it's on her land.
Tom dismisses this worry, confidently stating that discovered treasure belongs to the finder, regardless of whose land it is on.
This explanation satisfies Huck, and they resume their work.
After a while, Huck exclaims that they must be in the wrong place again and asks Tom for his opinion.
Tom finds the situation puzzling and suggests that witches might be interfering with their efforts.
Huck scoffs at this, reminding Tom that witches lack power during the daytime.
Tom acknowledges his oversight and then has a sudden insight: they need to find where the tree limb's shadow falls at midnight to locate the correct digging spot.
Huck bemoans their wasted effort and the necessity of returning at night, noting the long distance.
Tom insists they must return that very night, fearing that if someone discovers their current dig holes, the treasure's presence will be revealed.
Huck agrees to come back and signal Tom by meowing.
Tom suggests they hide their tools in nearby bushes.

They worked and sweated for half an hour. No result. They toiled another halfhour. Still no result. Huck said:
“Do they always bury it as deep as this?”
“Sometimes—not always. Not generally. I reckon we haven’t got the right place.”
So they chose a new spot and began again. The labor dragged a little, but still they made progress. They pegged away in silence for some time. Finally Huck leaned on his shovel, swabbed the beaded drops from his brow with his sleeve, and said:
“Where you going to dig next, after we get this one?”
“I reckon maybe we’ll tackle the old tree that’s over yonder on Cardiff Hill back of the widow’s.”
“I reckon that’ll be a good one. But won’t the widow take it away from us, Tom? It’s on her land.”
“She take it away! Maybe she’d like to try it once. Whoever finds one of these hid treasures, it belongs to him. It don’t make any difference whose land it’s on.”
That was satisfactory. The work went on. By and by Huck said:
“Blame it, we must be in the wrong place again. What do you think?”
“It is mighty curious, Huck. I don’t understand it. Sometimes witches interfere. I reckon maybe that’s what’s the trouble now.”
“Shucks! Witches ain’t got no power in the daytime.”
“Well, that’s so. I didn’t think of that. Oh, I know what the matter is! What a blamed lot of fools we are! You got to find out where the shadow of the limb falls at midnight, and that’s where you dig!”
“Then consound it, we’ve fooled away all this work for nothing. Now hang it all, we got to come back in the night. It’s an awful long way. Can you get out?”
“I bet I will. We’ve got to do it tonight, too, because if somebody sees these holes they’ll know in a minute what’s here and they’ll go for it.”
“Well, I’ll come around and maow tonight.”
“All right. Let’s hide the tools in the bushes.”

“Well, I don’t know. I reckon it’s a good place, but—”
“Say, Huck, I’ve got it! We’ve been digging in the wrong place! We ought to be over there, where the shadow of the limb falls at midnight!”
“By jings, Tom, that’s it! Why didn’t we think of that before? We’ve wasted all this work for nothing. Now we’ve got to come back to-night. It’s a long way.”
“Yes, I know, but we’ve got to come. If somebody sees these holes they’ll know there’s treasure buried here, and they’ll come and get it. We’ve got to come to-night and get it ourselves.”
“All right. I’ll come. When shall I come?”
“Come about midnight. I’ll be up and ready. You just meow outside my window.”
“All right. I’ll be there.”

events.title: The Spooky Nighttime Dig and Growing Fear
detailed_summary: The boys returned to the digging site that night around the agreed-upon time.
They sat quietly in the shadows, waiting for midnight.
The location felt isolated, and the hour was made more solemn by old superstitions.
Eerie sounds surrounded them: whispers in the rustling leaves, the distant baying of a hound, and an owl's mournful call, suggesting lurking spirits and ghosts.
The boys were subdued by the atmosphere and spoke very little.
When they judged it to be midnight, they identified where the shadow of the limb fell and commenced digging.
Their hopes began to rise, their interest intensified, and they worked diligently.
The hole grew deeper, but each time their pickaxe struck something, causing a hopeful jump, it was merely a stone or a piece of wood, leading to renewed disappointment.
Finally, Tom conceded that their efforts were futile and they were mistaken again.
Huck argued that they couldn't be wrong, as they had marked the shadow's position accurately.
Tom pointed out another potential error: they had only estimated the time, which might have been too early or too late for the correct shadow.
Huck, disheartened, dropped his shovel.
He agreed this was the issue and declared they had to abandon this spot, finding it impossible to determine the correct time.
Huck also expressed his intense fear of the nighttime setting, with its perceived witches and ghosts, feeling constantly watched and too afraid to look around for fear of what he might see.
Tom admitted he felt much the same way.
Tom added a chilling detail: treasure buried under a tree is often guarded by a dead man.
Huck was terrified by this notion, exclaiming his aversion to disturbing the dead.
Tom agreed, imagining a skull emerging and speaking, which further horrified Huck.
Both boys confessed to feeling extremely uncomfortable.
Huck proposed they give up on that location and try somewhere else.
Tom agreed it was probably for the best.
Huck then asked what their next option would be.

events.text_segment:
The boys were there that night, about the appointed time. They sat in the shadow waiting. It was a lonely place, and an hour made solemn by old traditions. Spirits whispered in the rustling leaves, ghosts lurked in the murky nooks, the deep baying of a hound floated up out of the distance, an owl answered with his sepulchral note. The boys were subdued by these solemnities, and talked little. By and by they judged that twelve had come; they marked where the shadow fell, and began to dig. Their hopes commenced to rise. Their interest grew stronger, and their industry kept pace with it. The hole deepened and still deepened, but every time their hearts jumped to hear the pick strike upon something, they only suffered a new disappointment. It was only a stone or a chunk. At last Tom said:
“It ain’t any use, Huck, we’re wrong again.”
“Well, but we can’t be wrong. We spotted the shadder to a dot.”
“I know it, but then there’s another thing.”
“What’s that?”
“Why, we only guessed at the time. Like enough it was too late or too early.”
Huck dropped his shovel.
“That’s it,” said he. “That’s the very trouble. We got to give this one up. We can’t ever tell the right time, and besides this kind of thing’s too awful, here this time of night with witches and ghosts a-fluttering around so. I feel as if something’s behind me all the time;  and I’m afeard to turn around, becuz maybe there’s others in front a-waiting for a chance. I been creeping all over, ever since I got here.”
“Well, I’ve been pretty much so, too, Huck. They most always put in a dead man when they bury a treasure under a tree, to look out for it.”
“Lordy!”
“Yes, they do. I’ve always heard that.”
“Tom, I don’t like to fool around much where there’s dead people. A body’s bound to get into trouble with ’em, sure.”
“I don’t like to stir ’em up, either. S’pose this one here was to stick his skull out and say something!”
“Don’t Tom! It’s awful.”
“Well, it just is. Huck, I don’t feel comfortable a bit.”
“Say, Tom, let’s give this place up, and try somewheres else.”
“All right, I reckon we better.”
“What’ll it be?”

LLM_completions.prefix-probing: The boys were there that night, about the appointed time. It was a fearsome place, the old graveyard, especially at midnight. The moon was struggling through ragged clouds, casting shifting, ghostly shadows among the leaning headstones and sunken graves. A chill wind sighed through the ancient oaks, making the dry leaves rustle like whispering secrets. Tom and Huck huddled behind a large clump of bushes near the edge of the woods, their hearts thumping against their ribs like trapped birds. Every snap of a twig, every distant hoot of an owl, sent a fresh wave of terror through them. They spoke in hushed whispers, if they spoke at all, mostly just gripping each other's arms in silent dread. They had brought a dead cat, as per the superstition, believing it could cure warts if buried at midnight in a graveyard where a wicked person was buried. But the warts were forgotten now, swallowed by the overwhelming fear of the place and the hour. Presently, they heard footsteps approaching. Three figures emerged from the gloom, carrying shovels and a pickaxe. Tom and Huck recognized them instantly, even in the poor light: Injun Joe, the half-breed; Muff Potter, the town drunkard; and young Dr. Robinson. The doctor seemed uneasy, while the other two looked grimly determined. They stopped near a fresh grave, one that had been dug only a few days prior. It was the grave of Hoss Williams. Injun Joe pointed to it, and the three men began their ghastly work. The scraping sound of the shovels biting into the earth was sickeningly loud in the stillness of the night. Tom and Huck watched, paralyzed by a mixture of horror and morbid fascination. They saw the dirt fly, heard the grunts of effort, and knew they were witnessing something terrible, something they should not be seeing. The air grew colder, and the shadows seemed to deepen around the working men. The boys dared not move, scarcely dared to breathe, lest they give away their presence. They were trapped witnesses to a sacrilege, and the night was only just beginning its dark revelations.

events.title: The Haunted House as the Next Target and Cautious Retreat
detailed_summary: After a period of reflection, Tom announced his new idea: the haunted house.
Huck immediately voiced his strong aversion to haunted houses, considering them far worse than places with dead bodies.

He elaborated that while dead people might talk, ghosts were more terrifying due to their silent, sudden appearances, such as sliding around in shrouds or peeking over one's shoulder and gritting their teeth.
Tom countered that ghosts are only active at night, so they could safely dig at the haunted house during the daytime.
Huck conceded this point but reminded Tom that people generally avoid the haunted house at all times, day or night.
Tom attributed this general avoidance to the fact that a man had been murdered there, but claimed that no regular ghosts had been seen, only occasional blue lights near the windows at night.
Huck argued that blue lights are a sure sign of a nearby ghost, as only ghosts use them.
Tom agreed with this logic but reiterated that since ghosts don't appear in the daytime, there was no reason for them to be afraid.
Huck reluctantly consented to try the haunted house, though he expressed his feeling that they were taking a significant chance.
By this point, the boys had begun their descent from the hill.

The narrative describes the appearance of the 'haunted' house below them in the moonlit valley: utterly isolated, its fences long gone, weeds choking the doorsteps, the chimney in ruins, window-sashes empty, and a section of the roof caved in.
The boys paused, observing the house for a while, half-anticipating the sight of a blue light flickering past a window.
Then, speaking in low tones appropriate for the time and circumstances, they decided to take a wide path around the haunted house, heading homeward through the woods at the back of Cardiff Hill.

events.text_segment:
Tom considered awhile; and then said:
“The ha’nted house. That’s it!”
“Blame it, I don’t like ha’nted houses, Tom. Why, they’re a dern sight worse’n dead people. Dead people might talk, maybe, but they don’t come sliding around in a shroud, when you ain’t noticing, and peep over your shoulder all of a sudden and grit their teeth, the way a ghost does. I couldn’t stand such a thing as that, Tom—nobody could.”
“Yes, but, Huck, ghosts don’t travel around only at night. They won’t hender us from digging there in the daytime.”
“Well, that’s so. But you know mighty well people don’t go about that ha’nted house in the day nor the night.”
“Well, that’s mostly because they don’t like to go where a man’s been murdered, anyway—but nothing’s ever been seen around that house except in the night—just some blue lights slipping by the windows—no regular ghosts.”
“Well, where you see one of them blue lights flickering around, Tom, you can bet there’s a ghost mighty close behind it. It stands to reason. Becuz you know that they don’t anybody but ghosts use ’em.”
“Yes, that’s so. But anyway they don’t come around in the daytime, so what’s the use of our being afeard?”
“Well, all right. We’ll tackle the ha’nted house if you say so—but I reckon it’s taking chances.”
They had started down the hill by this time. There in the middle of the moonlit valley below them stood the “ha’nted” house, utterly isolated, its fences gone long ago, rank weeds smothering the very doorsteps, the chimney crumbled to ruin, the window-sashes vacant, a corner of the roof caved in. The boys gazed awhile, half expecting to see a blue light flit past a window; then talking in a low tone, as befitted the time and the circumstances, they struck far off to the right, to give the haunted house a wide berth, and took their way homeward through the woods that adorned the rearward side of Cardiff Hill.

events.title: Friday Superstition and Postponement of Treasure Hunt
detailed_summary: Tom and Huck arrive at the dead tree near the haunted house, intending to retrieve their tools for digging.
Huck suddenly recalls that it is Friday, a day considered unlucky.
Tom concurs with Huck's superstition, acknowledging the potential danger of undertaking their planned activities on such a day.
Huck then mentions a disquieting dream he had about rats the previous night.
Tom interprets the dream: rats not fighting signifies surrounding trouble, advising caution.
They decide to abandon their haunted house plans for the day and engage in playing Robin Hood instead.
Tom proceeds to explain the character of Robin Hood to Huck, portraying him as a heroic figure who robbed the wealthy but aided the impoverished.
Huck expresses his admiration for Robin Hood and his lifestyle.
Tom further embellishes Robin Hood's legend, highlighting his exceptional combat and archery skills.
When Huck inquires about a 'yew bow,' Tom admits his ignorance but dismisses it as unimportant for their game.

The boys spend the remainder of the afternoon engrossed in their Robin Hood play, though they occasionally cast hopeful glances towards the haunted house, anticipating their activities there on the morrow.

About noon the next day the boys arrived at the dead tree; they had come for their tools. Tom was impatient to go to the haunted house; Huck was measurably so, also—but suddenly said:
“Lookyhere, Tom, do you know what day it is?”
Tom mentally ran over the days of the week, and then quickly lifted his eyes with a startled look in them—
“My! I never once thought of it, Huck!”
“Well, I didn’t neither, but all at once it popped onto me that it was Friday.”
“Blame it, a body can’t be too careful, Huck. We might ’a’ got into an awful scrape, tackling such a thing on a Friday.”
“Might! Better say we would! There’s some lucky days, maybe, but Friday ain’t.”
“Any fool knows that. I don’t reckon you was the first that found it out, Huck.”
“Well, I never said I was, did I? And Friday ain’t all, neither. I had a rotten bad dream last night—dreampt about rats.”
“No! Sure sign of trouble. Did they fight?”
“No.”
“Well, that’s good, Huck. When they don’t fight it’s only a sign that there’s trouble around, you know. All we got to do is to look mighty sharp and keep out of it. We’ll drop this thing for today, and play. Do you know Robin Hood, Huck?”
“No. Who’s Robin Hood?”
“Why, he was one of the greatest men that was ever in England—and the best. He was a robber.”
“Cracky, I wisht I was. Who did he rob?”
“Only sheriffs and bishops and rich people and kings, and such like. But he never bothered the poor. He loved ’em. He always divided up with ’em perfectly square.”
“Well, he must ’a’ been a brick.”
“I bet you he was, Huck. Oh, he was the noblest man that ever was. They ain’t any such men now, I can tell you. He could lick any man in England, with one hand tied behind him; and he could take his yew bow and plug a ten-cent piece every time, a mile and a half.”
“What’s a yew bow?”
“I don’t know. It’s some kind of a bow, of course. And if he hit that dime only on the edge he would set down and cry—and curse. But we’ll play Robin Hood—it’s nobby fun. I’ll learn you.”
“I’m agreed.”
So they played Robin Hood all the afternoon, now and then casting a yearning eye down upon the haunted house and passing a remark about the morrow’s prospects and possibilities there. As the sun began to sink into the west they took their way homeward athwart the long shadows of the trees and soon were buried from sight in the forests of Cardiff Hill.

About noon the next day the boys arrived at the dead tree; they had come for their tools. Tom was impatient to go to the haunted house; Huck was groaning with a headache, and he told Tom that all along he had been thinking of the gold and the robbers and a thousand things, and they had made him sick. They sat down on a log and rested. Suddenly Huck blurted out:
“Tom, now we’re about it. I reckon we hain’t got no business here at all—not to-day.”
Tom stopped wiping his perspiring face, and looked up in surprise.
“Why, what’s the matter?”
“Well, I tell you. It’s Friday.”
“That’s so! I never thought of that. You feel pretty shaky, don’t you?”
“If I feel shaky, Tom, I tell you it ain’t no wonder. If I’d a thought it was Friday I wouldn’t a come here for a million dollars. Lord, I can’t understand why I didn’t think of it before,” he said, slapping his forehead. “Oh, dear, oh, dear, it’s the unluckiest day in the month.”
“I know it. Why, I never heard of anybody that ever begun anything all great and good right on a Friday. No, sir; they always wait till Saturday, or some other day. But look here, Huck, ain’t Friday just as unlucky as Sunday?”
“Compared to Friday, Sunday is the luckiest day in the week. Why, I wouldn’t start out on a thing like this of a Friday, for anything. It’s dreadful bad luck. Ain’t you afeard?”
“I don’t know. I don’t wish we’d come here, to tell you the truth. But what can we do? We ain’t got any other place.”
“Well, that’s so. I hadn’t thought of that. I reckon we got to stand it. We can’t go home and leave the tools. Besides, they’d be expecting us. Oh, Gosh! And we ain’t got a bite to eat!”
“That’s so. I hain’t had a bite since breakfast. I wish I’d thought of it. But we can go to the haunted house, can’t we?”
“I don’t know. I don’t like the look of it. I wish we hadn’t come. I wish I hadn’t had that dream last night.”
“Dream? What did you dream about?”
“Well, I had such a bad dream about rats. I dreamt the house was full of rats, and they was all around me, and they was all fighting and squealing, and I couldn’t get away from them. And then I woke up, and I was so scared I couldn’t go to sleep again.”
“Rats? That’s bad luck, sure. What kind of rats?”
“Well, they was big rats, and little rats, and all kinds of rats. And they was all fighting and squealing, and I couldn’t get away from them.”
“Did they bite you?”
“No, they didn’t bite me. But they was all around me, and they was all fighting and squealing, and I couldn’t get away from them.”
“That’s bad luck, sure. Rats fighting and squealing, and you can’t get away from them. That means trouble. I reckon we better not go to the haunted house to-day. We can go to-morrow.”
“That’s what I think. We better not go to-day. We can go to-morrow. But what are we going to do to-day?”
“Well, we can play Robin Hood.”
“Robin Hood! That’s the best game there is. I like Robin Hood. He was a great man. He robbed the rich and gave to the poor. He was a friend of the poor.”
“That’s so. He was a great man. And he was a great fighter, too. He could fight with a sword, and he could shoot with a bow and arrow. He was the best archer in the world.”
“Did he have a yew bow?”
“I don’t know. I reckon he did. But it don’t make no difference. We can play Robin Hood anyway.”
So they played Robin Hood all the afternoon, and they had a good time. But they kept looking towards the haunted house, and they wished it was to-morrow.

events.title: Return to the Haunted House and Cautious Initial Exploration
detailed_summary: On Saturday, the boys return to the dead tree.
After a smoke and conversation, they undertake a brief and unfruitful dig in their previous excavation site, persuaded by Tom's assertion that treasures are often found by those who almost give up.
Content that they have fulfilled the obligations of treasure-hunting, they proceed towards the haunted house.
Upon reaching the house, its profound silence under the hot sun and its desolate, lonely appearance momentarily frighten them.

They cautiously approach the door and peer inside, observing a weed-filled, floorless room, unplastered walls, an old fireplace, empty window frames, a dilapidated staircase, and pervasive, neglected cobwebs.
With heightened senses and pounding hearts, they enter softly, speaking in whispers and remaining alert for any sound, prepared for a swift retreat.
As they grow more accustomed to the surroundings, their fears diminish, and they begin to examine the house with critical interest, admiring their own daring.
Their next objective is to explore the upstairs, a decision that feels like severing their escape route.
After mutual encouragement, they store their tools in a corner and ascend the stairs.
The upper floor exhibits the same level of decay as below; a closet that hinted at mystery reveals nothing.
With their courage now firm, they are on the verge of descending to commence their digging when Tom abruptly signals for quiet.

events.text_segment:
On Saturday, shortly after noon, the boys were at the dead tree again. They had a smoke and a chat in the shade, and then dug a little in their last hole, not with great hope, but merely because Tom said there were so many cases where people had given up a treasure after getting down within six inches of it, and then somebody else had come along and turned it up with a single thrust of a shovel. The thing failed this time, however, so the boys shouldered their tools and went away feeling that they had not trifled with fortune, but had fulfilled all the requirements that belong to the business of treasure-hunting.
When they reached the haunted house there was something so weird and grisly about the dead silence that reigned there under the baking sun, and something so depressing about the loneliness and desolation of the place, that they were afraid, for a moment, to venture in. Then they crept to the door and took a trembling peep. They saw a weedgrown, floorless room, unplastered, an ancient fireplace, vacant windows, a ruinous staircase; and here, there, and everywhere hung ragged and abandoned cobwebs. They presently entered, softly, with quickened pulses, talking in whispers, ears alert to catch the slightest sound, and muscles tense and ready for instant retreat.
In a little while familiarity modified their fears and they gave the place a critical and interested examination, rather admiring their own boldness, and wondering at it, too. Next they wanted to look upstairs. This was something like cutting off retreat, but they got to daring each other, and of course there could be but one result—they threw their tools into a corner and made the ascent. Up there were the same signs of decay. In one corner they found a closet that promised mystery, but the promise was a fraud—there was nothing in it. Their courage was up now and well in hand. They were about to go down and begin work when—

events.title: The Arrival and Unmasking of Injun Joe
detailed_summary: Tom urgently signals Huck to be quiet, having heard a sound.
Huck becomes terrified as Tom confirms the noise and indicates that people are approaching the door.
The boys quickly lie down on the floor, using knotholes in the planks to observe, consumed by fear.
Tom whispers that the individuals have arrived and warns Huck to remain absolutely silent.
Two men enter the house. The boys recognize one as the 'deaf and dumb Spaniard' they had seen in town previously; the other man is unfamiliar, with a ragged and unkempt appearance.
The 'Spaniard' is distinctively dressed in a serape, with bushy white whiskers, long white hair flowing from under his sombrero, and green goggles.
As the men enter, the unknown companion is speaking in a low voice; they sit on the ground near the door, and he continues his remarks, becoming less guarded.
The companion expresses concern that their plan is dangerous.
To the boys' astonishment, the 'deaf and dumb' Spaniard retorts, calling the companion a 'Milksop' for thinking it dangerous.
The voice causes the boys to gasp and tremble; they realize it is Injun Joe.
Following a tense silence, Injun Joe speaks, dismissing the current plan's danger by comparing it to a less successful venture up the river.
The companion argues the previous situation was different due to its isolated location.
Injun Joe counters by pointing out the risk of being seen entering the haunted house in broad daylight.
He reveals he had intended to leave the previous day but was prevented by the sight of 'those infernal boys' (Tom and Huck) playing nearby on the hill, in full view.
Hearing themselves mentioned, Tom and Huck are further terrified, appreciating their luck in postponing their visit due to Friday, and now wishing they had delayed it for a year.
